messageBody:
I'd like to point out here that this is my first post to this
group. I've been using Shavian for a few years, and I'm starting to
get into QuikScript, now.

Anyway, back to the topic, keyman does not work on Mac OS. It is
possible to make a keyboard driver that will do the same thing, but
I don't think it can be done with the XML format. XML keyboard
drivers are, as far as I know, simply different keyboard layouts
with no such advanced features. It is possible to create such a
driver, but I don't know how. Your best bet is probably to write a
stand-alone program to do the conversion for you.

This could also be handled by more advanced fonts. OpenType fonts
allow scripting that can be used to substitute ligatures for
separate letters. For example, in a standard roman font, you might
find:

sub f i by fi;
sub f l by fl;

I'm not sure that's entirely correct, but you get the idea. For
QuikScript, you could do something like this:

sub y r by R;
sub Y r by P;

This would automatically replace these letter sequences with
ligatures.

--- In Read_Alphabet@yahoogroups.com, "Jean-François Colson"
<jfcolson@b...> wrote:
>
> I'm afraid it doesn't work on a Mac, except perhaps if you use a
Windows emulator - I don't know, I
> have no Mac.
> I've made that driver for myself, for my personal use, and I
decided to share it with other
> interested users of Windows.
> I you have a Mac and you know how to do it, you could make a
keyboard driver in XML or by using the
> Keyboard Builder
(http://www.versiontracker.com/dyn/moreinfo/macosx/20953). I can't
try it now.
>
> JF
